learning_outcomes: Categorize viruses based on their structural characteristics, strand composition, associated diseases, and host organisms
Recognize the clinical manifestations, transmission pathways, and causative agent of AIDS
Summarize the cellular respiration pathways for proteins and fats, comparing them to glucose metabolism
Provide definitions and classification schemes for biological molecules
Explain the significance of biological molecules in living systems
Characterize biologically significant properties of water including polarity, hydrolysis, specific heat capacity, solvent capability, reagent function, density, cohesion, and ionization
Explain carbohydrates including monosaccharides such as glucose, oligosaccharides such as sucrose and lactose, and polysaccharides including starches, cellulose, and glycogen
Characterize proteins focusing on amino acid composition and structural organization
Characterize lipids including phospholipids, triglycerides, and esters such as acylglycerol
Provide an overview of RNA structure and function
Explain conjugated molecules including glycolipids and glycoproteins
Describe the Watson-Crick double helix model of DNA structure
Identify a gene as a nucleotide sequence within DNA that encodes for polypeptide formation
Contrast the structural features of typical animal and plant cells
Distinguish between the structural characteristics of prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells
Detail the structure and function of nucleus, endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi apparatus, and mitochondria
Characterize chromosome structure, chemical composition, and functional role
Identify receptors as transducers that respond to diverse stimuli
Describe the structural components of a typical neuron including cell body, dendrites, axon, and myelin sheath
Provide a definition of nerve impulse
Categorize different types of reflexes
Explain the functional roles of reflex arc components
Explain the major divisions of the brain including brain stem components, midbrain, cerebellum, and cerebrum
Characterize the functions of each brain region
Characterize the distinguishing properties of enzymes
Describe the mechanism by which enzymes catalyze reactions

topics.topic_name: Factors that Affect the Rate of Enzyme Reactions
learning_outcomes: Characterize how temperature, pH, and concentration affect enzyme activity
Characterize enzyme inhibitors and their effects
Describe the origin of life according to evolutionary concepts
Characterize Lamarck's theory of inheritance of acquired characteristics
Describe Darwin's theory of natural selection
Characterize the functions of male and female reproductive system components and their regulatory hormones
Characterize the menstrual cycle with emphasis on hormonal regulation
Identify common sexually transmitted diseases, their causative agents, and primary symptoms
Characterize cartilage, muscle, and bone
Describe the primary characteristics and functions of cartilage and bone
Contrast the characteristics of smooth, cardiac, and skeletal muscles
Describe the ultrastructure of skeletal muscle tissue
Provide a concise description of the skeletal muscle contraction mechanism
Categorize different types of joints
Provide a definition of arthritis
Connect inheritance patterns to Mendel's laws
Describe the law of independent assortment using appropriate examples
Characterize gene linkage and crossing over
Describe how gene linkage opposes independent assortment and how crossing over alters offspring characteristics
Characterize the concept of sex-linkage
Provide a concise description of sex-linked trait inheritance
Examine the inheritance pattern of hemophilia
Explain the general structure of the human heart

topics.topic_name: Cardiac Cycle and Phases of Heartbeat
learning_outcomes: Characterize the phases of the heartbeat
Enumerate the differences and functions of arteries, veins, and capillaries
Characterize the lymphatic system including nodes, vessels, and organs
Provide definitions and explain the functions and importance of specific defense mechanisms
Explain the functions of the main components of the respiratory system
Explain the gas exchange process in human lungs
Explain the effects of smoking on the respiratory system
Characterize the components of the human digestive system
Describe the functions of the main digestive organs including associated structures and glands
Describe the components of the urinary system and relate kidney structure to its function
Describe the processes of glomerular filtration, selective reabsorption, and tubular secretion in kidney function
Explain how kidneys function in both excretion and osmoregulation
Contrast the function of glomerular capillaries and peritubular capillaries in the kidney
Describe the causes and treatments of kidney stones
Identify the causes of kidney failure
Characterize thermoregulation and explain its necessity
Identify various nitrogenous compounds eliminated during excretion
Characterize how biotechnologists address health problems through vaccine production
Explain the role of biotechnology in disease diagnosis using DNA/RNA probes and monoclonal antibodies
Characterize products obtained by biotechnologists for disease treatment
Develop mole ratios from balanced equations for use as conversion factors in stoichiometric calculations
Execute stoichiometric calculations with balanced equations using moles, representative particles, masses, and gas volumes at standard temperature
Describe the limiting reagent concept in chemical reactions
Determine the maximum amount of products formed and the quantity of any unreacted excess reagent
When provided with information to determine any two of the following, calculate the third: theoretical yield, actual yield, percentage yield
Determine the theoretical yield and percent yield given the balanced equation, reactant amounts, and actual yield
Characterize the discovery and properties of protons (positive rays)
Identify a photon as a unit of radiation energy
Characterize the concept of orbitals
Differentiate among principal energy level, energy sub-level, and atomic orbitals
Characterize the general shapes of s, p, and d orbitals
Characterize the hydrogen atom using quantum theory
Apply the Aufbau principle, Pauli Exclusion Principle, and Hund's Rule to write electronic configurations of atoms
Write the electronic configuration of atoms
Enumerate the postulates of Kinetic Molecular Theory
Characterize the motion of gas particles according to kinetic theory
Specify the values of standard temperature and pressure
Characterize the effect of pressure changes on gas volume
Characterize the effect of temperature changes on gas volume
Describe the significance of absolute zero and specify its value in degrees
Derive the ideal gas equation using Boyle's Law, Charles's Law, and Avogadro's Law
Describe the significance and different units of the ideal gas constant
Differentiate between real and ideal gases

topics.topic_name: Properties of Liquids Based on Kinetic Molecular Theory
learning_outcomes: Characterize simple properties of liquids such as diffusion, compression, expansion, molecular motion, intermolecular spaces, intermolecular forces, and kinetic energy based on kinetic molecular theory

topics.topic_name: Evaporation, Boiling Point and Vapor Pressure
learning_outcomes: Describe physical properties of liquids including evaporation, vapor pressure, and boiling point
Characterize hydrogen bonding in H2O, NH3, and HF molecules
Describe the anomalous behavior of water where density reaches maximum at 4 degrees centigrade
Characterize crystalline solids

topics.topic_name: Factors Affecting the Shape of Ionic Crystals
learning_outcomes: Identify three factors that influence the shape of ionic crystals

topics.topic_name: Difference Between Ionic and Molecular Crystals
learning_outcomes: Provide concise descriptions of ionic and molecular crystals
Describe the structure of a crystal lattice
Provide a definition of lattice energy

Describe the terms rate of reaction and rate equation

Specify the order with respect to the reactant and write the rate law for the reaction
Describe the meaning of activation energy and activated complex
Connect the concepts of activation energy and activated complex to reaction rate
Characterize the role of the rate constant in theoretical reaction rate determination

Categorize reactions as exothermic or endothermic

Identify and define the units of internal energy

Apply Hess's Law to develop simple energy cycles
Characterize enthalpy of reaction
Identify the characteristics of a redox reaction

Define cathode, anode, electrode potential, and standard hydrogen electrode

topics.topic_name: Definition and Classification of Organic Compound
learning_outcomes: Define organic chemistry and organic compounds

Define functional group
Describe stereoisomerism and its types

topics.topic_name: MOT of Benzene Resonance and Resonance Energy
learning_outcomes: Describe the shape of benzene molecules using molecular orbital treatment

topics.topic_name: Nomenclature, Structure and Reactivity of Phenols

topics.topic_name: Nomenclature and Structure of Aldehydes and Ketones
learning_outcomes: Describe nomenclature and structure of aldehydes and ketones

Explain the chemistry of aldehydes and ketones through reduction to alcohols

learning_outcomes: Characterize nomenclature, structure, and preparation of carboxylic acids

Characterize the role of enzymes as biocatalysts

Understand types of dyes and their uses
Understand condensation and addition polymers and their sub-types

Characterize the scalar product of two vectors in terms of the angle between them
Characterize the vector product of two vectors in terms of the angle between them

Characterize average velocity of objects
Analyze displacement-time graphs of objects moving along the same straight line

topics.topic_name: Projectile Motion: Maximum Height, Range, Time of Flight, Maximum Angle
learning_outcomes: Calculate, using equations of uniformly accelerated motion for a given initial velocity of a frictionless projectile: maximum height, horizontal range, position after a given time, time in air, parameters for a projectile launched from ground height, launch angle for maximum range, and relation between launch angles that result in the same range
Apply Newton's laws to explain object motion in various contexts

learning_outcomes: Characterize Newton's second law of motion as the rate of change of momentum

Characterize that momentum is conserved in various situations

topics.topic_name: Perfectly Elastic Collision in One Dimension
learning_outcomes: Recognize that for a perfectly elastic collision, the relative speed of approach equals the relative speed of separation

Characterize energy

Describe the difference between potential energy and gravitational potential energy
Characterize that gravitational potential energy is measured from a reference level and can be positive or negative, denoting orientation from the reference level
Express power as the scalar product of force and velocity

topics.topic_name: Work Energy Theorem in Resistive Medium
learning_outcomes: Describe that work done against friction is dissipated as heat in the environment

learning_outcomes: Explain the implications of energy losses in practical devices

Characterize angular velocity

topics.topic_name: Relation Between Angular and Linear Quantities
learning_outcomes: Identify the relationship between linear and angular variables, displacements, velocities, and accelerations

Define and describe fluid drag

Recognize that the equation of continuity is a form of the principle of conservation of mass
Interpret and apply Bernoulli's effect in blood physics

Characterize wave motion as illustrated by vibrations in ropes and springs

Solve problems using the equation v = f

learning_outcomes: Identify the factors on which sound speed in air depends

Describe the formation of stationary waves using graphical methods

learning_outcomes: Characterize modes of vibration of strings

Sketch the electric field lines for two point charges of equal magnitude with same or opposite signs

topics.topic_name: Electric Field Intensity Due to an Infinite Sheet of Charges
learning_outcomes: Characterize and draw the electric field due to an infinite conducting plate of positive or negative charge

Derive an expression for electric potential at a point due to a point charge

learning_outcomes: Demonstrate charging and discharging of a capacitor through a resistance

Characterize the concept of magnetic flux  as scalar product of magnetic field B and area A using the relation B = BA = BA

topics.topic_name: Motion of Charged Particle in Magnetic Field

topics.topic_name: Biological and Medical Uses of Radiation
learning_outcomes: Characterize biological effects of radiation and explain different medical uses of radiation
Rapidly review text to answer brief questions

Examine how a writer or poet uses language to appeal to the senses through figurative language

topics.topic_name: Formal and Lexical Aspect of Language
learning_outcomes: Infer the meaning of difficult words from context using contextual clues

Demonstrate use of pronoun-antecedent agreement
Demonstrate use of tenses
Demonstrate use of infinitives and infinitive phrases
Demonstrate the use of gerunds and gerund phrases

Proofread and edit their own, peers', and given text for errors of usage and style

Identify subject-verb agreement errors
Identify errors of function and spelling
Construct logical arguments for statements to be true or false
Provide reasons for the right beliefs
Recognize and critically evaluate false beliefs using logical reasoning
Construct arithmetical operations as per numbers
Construct geometrical progressions as per numbers
Construct series/sequential orders as per letters and symbols (according to specific rules)
Infer new relations on the basis of given relations
Construct new structures on the basis of information in already drawn structures

Construct skills to solve puzzles
Construct skills to gather different parts of information
